title: R43898
content: Recent legislation has extended certain expiring tax provisions and made some temporary provisions permanent, reducing tax policy uncertainty. The American Taxpayer Relief Act (ATRA) permanently extended most tax cuts from 2001 and 2003, as well as indexed the alternative minimum tax (AMT) for inflation. The Tax Increase Prevention Act of 2014 retroactively extended provisions that expired in 2013 through 2014. Several tax provisions that expired in 2011, 2012, and 2013 were temporarily extended through 2014. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2016 made permanent or temporarily extended all tax provisions that had expired in 2014. These temporary tax provisions, often referred to as "tax extenders," have been regularly extended by Congress. For example, the research tax credit was extended 16 times before being made permanent in 2016. In the 114th Congress, the debate on tax extenders focused on whether expired provisions should be made permanent or temporarily extended. In P.L. 114-113, all expired tax provisions were either temporarily extended or made permanent, reducing uncertainty in the tax code. However, not all expired provisions were made permanent, leaving some tax extenders set to expire in 2016. The tax extenders debate in the 114th Congress focused on making expired provisions permanent or temporarily extending them. While some provisions were made permanent, not all were, leaving some tax extenders set to expire in 2016. Further debate may address whether these provisions should be extended. The Consolidated Omnibus Appropriations Act, 2016 (P.L. 114-113) contained the Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes Act of 2015 (PATH Act), which temporarily extended or made various tax provisions permanent. Other related CRS reports include recently expired business, individual, charitable, community assistance-related, and housing-related tax provisions. The Consolidated Omnibus Appropriations Act, 2016 (P.L. 114-113) included the Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes Act of 2015 (PATH Act), which extended or made permanent various tax provisions. This Act also made enhancements to child tax credit, American Opportunity Tax Credit, and earned income tax credit permanent, along with a two-year moratorium on the medical device excise tax. Additionally, it included changes to the high-cost employer-sponsored health coverage excise tax and a one-year moratorium on the annual fee on health insurance providers. The PATH Act in the Consolidated Omnibus Appropriations Act, 2016 extended or made permanent various tax provisions, including enhancements to child tax credit, American Opportunity Tax Credit, and earned income tax credit. It also included a two-year moratorium on the medical device excise tax, changes to the high-cost employer-sponsored health coverage excise tax, and a one-year moratorium on the annual fee on health insurance providers. The Tax Relief Extension Act of 2015 aimed to extend various tax provisions, including the R&D tax credit and increased expensing allowances, that had expired in 2014 for two years. The tax code contains numerous temporary provisions, often referred to as "tax extenders," which are regularly extended by Congress for short periods. The term "tax extender" refers to expiring tax provisions temporarily extended by Congress for short periods. These provisions are added over time for various reasons such as evaluating effectiveness, providing relief during economic weakness or disasters, and for budgetary reasons. In theory, temporary tax provisions allow Congress to evaluate effectiveness before extension. Reasons for temporary provisions include providing relief during economic weakness or disasters and for budgetary purposes. Enacting temporary tax provisions allows for evaluation before extension, but if regularly extended without review, the rationale is undermined. Instead, expiring provisions are typically passed as a package without individual analysis. Policymakers must prioritize economic objectives when deciding on extenders. Tax extenders are evaluated based on economic efficiency, equity, and simplicity. They may provide subsidies to encourage certain activities, but their impact on economic welfare depends on whether they address market failures. Extenders can improve economic efficiency by remedying distortions, but policymakers must prioritize economic objectives when deciding on them. Tax extenders can improve economic efficiency by addressing market failures and tax distortions. They may stimulate desired activities better than direct subsidies, but direct spending programs can be more effective at targeting resources. Fairness in taxes is achieved when they contribute to a socially desirable distribution of the tax burden, but tax extenders can result in varying tax amounts for individuals with similar incomes and expenses. Tax extenders can lead to unequal tax burdens for individuals with similar incomes, deviating from the principles of horizontal equity. Dozens of temporary tax provisions were extended in P.L. 114-113, classified into individual, business, charitable, or energy categories. Most provisions extended in P.L. 114-113 were part of previous tax extender legislation, categorized into individual, business, charitable, or energy. The above-the-line deduction for classroom expenses for school teachers was made permanent in this legislation. The above-the-line deduction for classroom expenses for school teachers, state and local sales taxes deduction, tuition and related expenses deduction, mortgage insurance premiums deduction, and parity for employer-provided mass transit and parking benefits were extended multiple times and made permanent in P.L. 114-113.
